topic.title: Interlaken <-> MAC <-> OTN Datapaths

li.p: 10-100G frames via Ethernet MAC and adapted for GFP Clause 6.2 mapping into OTN without preamble (5a).
10G (5b), 25G (5c), 50G (5d), 200G (5f), 400G (5g) frames via Ethernet MAC and adapted for BMP mapping into OTN.
100G frames via Ethernet MAC and adapted for GMP mapping into OTN (5e).
Flexible rate frames via Ethernet MAC using IMP adaption for BMP mapping into OTN (5h).

On the receive path, packets are received over the Interlaken interface, go through the COPI subsystem and get stored in the DCPB packet buffer. The MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_E provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities. The MAC adds the preamble, idles and ordered sets. Finally, the MAC encodes the data into 66b code words. The rate of the TX MAC is provided by a virtual and nominal rate SERDES. The resulting code word stream can be CBR mapped into OTN using BMP, GMP or IMP. Alternatively, it could be GFP mapped into OTN.

For BMP and GMP, the FEMP assembles the code words and forwards them into the ECPB mapping buffer. The MAPOTN subsystem then retrieves the code words and maps them into BMP for 10GE/25GE/50GE/400GE or GMP for 100GE. The BMP traffic is nominal rate, while the GMP traffic is mapped with a nominal Cn. The rate information is given to the MAPOTN outside of the ENET subsystem.

For ODUflex IMP mapping, all idles are deleted by the FEMP and packets are sent to the ECPB buffer. The IMP_MAP block within the MAPOTN then inserts idles to create a nominal rate stream by listening to the ECPB buffer FIFO zone. The nominal rate information is given to the MAPOTN subsystem outside of the ENET.

For GFP mapping, the FEMP performs packet delineation, stripping all idles and ordered sets. Packets are then sent across the ECPB mapping buffer. The MAPOTN extract these packets and performs the GFP map.
On the transmit path, the MAPOTN subsystem demaps the traffic from BMP, GMP, IMP or GFP.

The MAPOTN demaps the 10GE/25GE/50GE/400GE from BMP or the 100GE from GMP and stores the code words in the ECPB demapping buffer. Data then goes through the FEDP that performs demapping adaptation functions. The traffic then passes through the MAC which delineates Ethernet packets, deleting preamble, all idles and O/S. These packets are forwarded and stored in the DCPB packet buffer. The MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_I provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities. The packets are then extracted from DCPB packet buffer, go through the COPI subsystem and are delivered over the Interlaken interface.

When demapping from ODUflex IMP, the IMP_DEMAP block within the MAPOTN deletes all idles and stores packets in the ECPB demapping buffer. Data then goes to the FEDP which performs demapping adaptation functions. The FEDP then creates as many idles as required to create a nominal rate stream. A virtual SERDES provides information to the FEDP to create that nominal rate stream. The traffic then passes through the MAC which delineates Ethernet packets, deleting preamble, all idles and ordered sets. These packets are forwarded and stored in the DCPB packet buffer. The MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_I provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities. The packets are then extracted from the DCPB packet buffer, go through the COPI subsystem and are delivered over the Interlaken interface.

For GFP, the MAPOTN extracts the packets and stores them in the ECPB. The FEDP extracts these packets, adds the preamble, idles and ordered sets. The traffic then passes through the RX MAC which delineates Ethernet packets, deleting preamble, all idles and ordered sets. These packets are forwarded and stored in the DCPB packet buffer. The MAC provides full PMON while the FEPP_I provides packet insertion and extraction capabilities. The packets are then extracted from DCPB packet buffer, go through the COPI subsystem and are delivered over the Interlaken interface.
